short_bio: Melissa Leong is a food and travel writer, radio broadcaster, television presenter, and cookbook editor. She is a regular judge on MasterChef Australia.

recipes.cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Mix together the miso paste, soy sauce, honey, and sesame oil in a bowl. Place the chicken thighs in a baking dish and spoon the miso mixture over them. Bake in the oven for 30-35 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through. Serve hot.

Cook the linguine in a large pot of salted boiling water until al dente. Meanwhile, heat the olive oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the garlic and chilli, and cook for 1-2 minutes. Add the crab meat and stir through. Drain the pasta and add it to the pan with the crab sauce. Toss to combine and serve immediately.

ingredients: 500g squid, cleaned and sliced into rings
recipes.cooking_method: In a bowl, mix together the cornflour, plain flour, sea salt, and black pepper. Coat the squid rings in the flour mixture, shaking off any excess. Heat a deep-fryer or large saucepan of oil to 180°C. Fry the squid in batches for 1-2 minutes, or until golden brown and crispy. Drain on paper towels and serve hot with lemon wedges and aioli.

short_bio: Dan Hunter is the executive chef and owner of Brae, a restaurant in Birregurra, Victoria, Australia. He has worked at some of the world's best restaurants, including Mugaritz in Spain and The Fat Duck in the UK. At Brae, he focuses on using local, seasonal ingredients to create dishes that are both elegant and simple.

recipes.cooking_method: Preheat oven to 375°F. Rub chicken with salt and pepper. Cut vegetables into large pieces and place in roasting pan. Place chicken on top of vegetables and roast in oven for 1 hour.

Heat chicken stock in a saucepan. In a separate pan, sauté mushrooms, onion, and garlic until soft. Add Arborio rice and stir to coat. Gradually add hot chicken stock, stirring constantly, until rice is cooked through. Serve with a sprinkle of fresh thyme.

Preheat oven to 325°F. Season beef short ribs with salt and pepper. Sear the beef in a Dutch oven or heavy pot until browned on all sides. Remove the beef and set aside. Add onion and garlic to the pot and sauté until softened. Add the red wine and beef broth and bring to a boil. Return the beef to the pot and cover. Cook in the oven for 2-3 hours until the beef is tender and falls off the bone. Serve with mashed potatoes or roasted vegetables.

short_bio: Emma Dean is an Australian chef, cookbook author, and television presenter. She won the fifth season of MasterChef Australia in 2013 and has since released her own cookbook. Emma is passionate about using fresh, locally sourced ingredients and often incorporates native Australian ingredients into her dishes.

recipes.cooking_method: Heat oil in a large pot or tagine. Brown the lamb shoulder and remove from the pot. Add chopped onion and garlic and sauté until softened. Add sweet potato, carrot, and zucchini to the pot and sauté for a few minutes. Add the lamb back to the pot and cover with water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 1-2 hours, until the lamb is tender. Serve with couscous or rice.

recipes.recipe_name: Grilled barramundi with lemon and herbs
ingredients: 1 tbsp chopped fresh herbs (such as parsley, thyme, or oregano)
recipes.cooking_method: Preheat grill to high heat. Season barramundi fillets with salt and pepper. Grill for 3-4 minutes on each side, until cooked through. Squeeze fresh lemon juice over the fish and sprinkle with chopped herbs before serving.

Preheat oven to 350°F. Grease a 9-inch cake pan. Combine flour, baking powder, wattleseed, macadamia nuts, and sugar in a bowl. In a separate bowl, whisk together milk, eggs, and vegetable oil. Add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients and mix until just combined. Pour the batter into the prepared cake pan and bake for 30-35 minutes, until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Let cool before slicing and serving.

short_bio: Curtis Stone is an Australian celebrity chef, television personality, and author. He has hosted numerous cooking shows, including 'Take Home Chef', 'Top Chef Masters', and 'Around the World in 80 Plates'. Curtis is known for his simple and seasonal approach to cooking, and his passion for using fresh ingredients.

recipes.cooking_method: Slice the pork into thin strips. Clean and slice the mushrooms. Cut the bell pepper into thin strips. Mince the garlic and grate the ginger. In a small bowl, whisk together soy sauce, oyster sauce, cornstarch, and 1/4 cup water. Heat the vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Add the pork and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes, until browned. Add the mushrooms, bell pepper, garlic, and ginger and stir-fry for another 2-3 minutes, until the vegetables are softened. Pour in the sauce and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes, until the sauce has thickened and coated the ingredients. Serve with steamed rice.

Season salmon fillets with salt and pepper. Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add salmon fillets and cook for 3-4 minutes on each side, until cooked through. In a separate bowl, combine diced avocado, tomato, red onion, cilantro, lime juice, and a pinch of salt. Serve the salmon with the avocado salsa on top.

Preheat oven to 375°F. Rinse the chicken and pat dry with paper towels. Cut the lemon into quarters and stuff inside the chicken cavity with the thyme sprigs and garlic cloves. Truss the chicken and place in a roasting pan. Drizzle olive oil over the chicken and season with salt and pepper. Roast for 1 hour and 15 minutes, until the internal temperature reaches 165°F. Let the chicken rest for 10 minutes before carving and serving.

short_bio: Maggie Beer is an Australian chef, food author, and television personality. She is known for her focus on seasonal and local ingredients, and for her signature product, verjuice. Maggie has written many cookbooks and hosted several television shows, including 'The Cook and the Chef'. She is also a passionate advocate for regional Australian food and wine.

recipes.recipe_name: Roast chicken with verjuice and rosemary
recipes.cooking_method: Preheat oven to 375°F. Rinse the chicken and pat dry with paper towels. Cut the garlic cloves in half and stuff inside the chicken cavity with the rosemary sprigs. Truss the chicken and place in a roasting pan. Drizzle olive oil and verjuice over the chicken and season with salt and pepper. Roast for 1 hour and 15 minutes, until the internal temperature reaches 165°F. Let the chicken rest for 10 minutes before carving and serving.

ingredients: 1 lb mixed summer berries (raspberries, strawberries, blackberries, blueberries)
recipes.cooking_method: In a large saucepan, heat the berries and sugar over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the sugar has dissolved and the berries have released their juices. Cut the crusts off the bread slices and line the bottom and sides of a 2-quart pudding basin with them, slightly overlapping the slices. Pour the berry mixture into the bread-lined basin and cover the top with more bread slices. Place a small plate on top of the bread and weigh down with a heavy can or jar. Refrigerate overnight. To serve, remove the weight and plate, and invert the pudding onto a serving platter. Serve with cream.

recipes.recipe_name: Veal saltimbocca with sage and prosciutto
recipes.cooking_method: Place each veal cutlet between two sheets of plastic wrap and pound with a meat mallet until thin. Season with salt and pepper. Place a sage leaf and a slice of prosciutto on top of each cutlet and secure with a toothpick. Dredge the cutlets in flour, shaking off any excess. Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the cutlets and cook for 2-3 minutes on each side, until browned and cooked through. Remove the cutlets from the skillet and keep warm. Add the white wine to the skillet and deglaze, scraping up any browned bits. Reduce the wine by half, then whisk in the butter until melted and smooth. Serve the veal saltimbocca with the white wine sauce spooned over the top. Garnish with additional sage leaves if desired.

short_bio: Peter Gilmore is an Australian chef and restaurateur, known for his innovative and artistic approach to food. He has been the executive chef of Quay Restaurant in Sydney since 2001, where he has led the restaurant to be consistently ranked as one of the best in Australia and the world. Peter is also a published author, with two cookbooks showcasing his culinary philosophy and signature dishes.

recipes.recipe_name: Marron with kelp butter and fermented shiitake
recipes.cooking_method: Bring a large pot of water to the boil. Drop the marron into the water and cook for 2-3 minutes. Remove the marron from the water and allow them to cool slightly. Twist off the claws and reserve them. Cut the marron in half lengthways and remove the intestinal tract. Place a sheet of kelp on each half, then top with a knob of butter. Bake in the oven at 200°C for 10-12 minutes. Meanwhile, finely chop the reserved claws and sauté in a pan until lightly caramelised. Add the shiitake mushrooms, soy sauce, mirin, and sugar, and cook for another minute. Remove the kelp from the marron and serve with the mushroom mixture spooned over the top.

Place the egg whites in a stand mixer and whisk until stiff peaks form. Gradually add the sugar, whisking continuously, until the mixture is thick and glossy. In a saucepan, heat the milk, vanilla bean, and lemon myrtle leaves over medium heat until just below boiling. Remove from heat, strain the mixture, and add the gelatine leaves. Stir to dissolve the gelatine, then allow the mixture to cool. Fill a large bowl with liquid nitrogen. Use a slotted spoon to carefully lower spoonfuls of the egg white mixture into the nitrogen. Remove them once they are frozen, and place them in a container in the freezer. Repeat until all the mixture is used. To serve, place a frozen egg white ball on a bed of lemon myrtle leaves. Pour the chilled milk mixture over the egg white ball and serve immediately.

recipes.recipe_name: Slow cooked beef short rib with beetroot and blackberry
recipes.cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 160°C. Season the short ribs with salt and pepper. Heat the olive oil in a large oven-safe pot or Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Brown the short ribs on all sides, then remove from the pot and set aside. Add the garlic and rosemary to the pot and sauté for 1-2 minutes, until fragrant. Add the balsamic vinegar, honey, beef stock, and blackberries, and bring to a boil. Return the short ribs to the pot and cover with a lid. Transfer the pot to the preheated oven and cook for 3-4 hours, until the meat is tender and falls off the bone. While the short ribs are cooking, peel and dice the beetroot into small cubes. Heat a small amount of olive oil in a frying pan over medium heat, and sauté the beetroot cubes for 5-7 minutes, until slightly caramelised. Season with salt and pepper. Serve the short ribs with the beetroot cubes and sauce spooned over the top.
